[1161] 3 - As for what Muhammad ibn al-Hasan al-Saffar narrated, from Muhammad ibn al-Husayn, from Musa ibn Sa'dan, from al-Husayn ibn Hammad, from Ishaq, from Umar ibn Yazid, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: Whoever enters Mecca for 'Umrah and stays until the crescent of Dhu al-Hijjah, then he is not allowed to leave until he performs Hajj with the people.
[1162] 4 - And what Musa ibn al-Qasim narrated: He said: Some of our companions told me that he asked Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) in the first ten days of Shawwal, saying: I want to perform a separate 'Umrah this month. فالوجه في هذين الخبرين أحد شيئين، أحدهما: أن نحملهما على ضرب من الاستحباب، والآخر أن نحملهما على من كانت عمرته متعة فإنه لا يجوز له أن يخرج لأنه مرتهن بالحج على ما تضمنه الخبران، وليس في الخبرين أن العمرة كانت مفردة أو كانت التي يتمتع بها إلى الحج بل هي مجملة ونحن نحملها على هذا التفصيل لئلا تتناقض الاخبار، يدل على هذا المعنى:
[1163] 5 - ما رواه محمد بن يعقوب عن علي بن إبراهيم عن أبيه عن إسماعيل بن مرار عن يونس عن معاوية بن عمار قال: قلت لأبي عبد الله عليه السلام من أين افترق المتمتع والمعتمر؟ فقال: إن المتمتع مرتبط بالحج والمعتمر إذا فرغ منها ذهب حيث شاء وقد اعتمر الحسين عليه السلام في ذي الحجة ثم راح يوم التروية إلى العراق والناس يروحون إلى منى فلا بأس بالعمرة في ذي الحجة لمن لا يريد الحج.
[1164] 6 - وروى محمد بن الحسن الصفار عن محمد بن الحسين عن وهيب بن حفص عن علي عليه السلام قال: سأله أبو بصير وأنا حاضر عمن أهل بعمرة في أشهر الحج له أن يرجع؟ قال: ليس في أشهر الحج عمرة يرجع فيها إلى أهله ولكنه يحتبس بمكة حتى يقضي حجه لأنه إنما أحرم لذلك.
فبين عليه السلام في هذا الخبر أنه لم يجز له ذلك لأنه أحرم للحج وهذا لا يكون إلا لمن قصد التمتع بالعمرة إلى الحج على ما بيناه.
226 - باب أن البدأة بالمدينة أفضل لمن حج على طريق العراق [1165] 1 - روى موسى بن القاسم عن صفوان عن عيص بن القاسم قال: سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام عن الحاج من الكوفة يبدأ بالمدينة أفضل أو بمكة؟ قال: بالمدينة.

The explanation regarding these two narrations involves one of two possibilities: either we interpret them as a form of recommendation, or we interpret them as applying to someone whose ‘Umrah is a Tamattu‘ (combining ‘Umrah with Hajj), for it is not permissible for him to leave because he is bound to the Hajj, as implied by the two narrations. The narrations do not specify whether the ‘Umrah was Mufradah (single) or the one performed as Tamattu‘ until Hajj; rather, it is general. We interpret it according to this detail so that the narrations do not contradict each other. Supporting this meaning is:
[1163] 5 - What Muhammad ibn Ya'qub narrated from Ali ibn Ibrahim from his father from Ismail ibn Marrar from Yunus from Mu'awiyah ibn Ammar, who said: I said to Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him): From where is the difference between the Mutamatti' (one performing Tamattu') and the Mu'tamir (one performing 'Umrah)? He said: The Mutamatti' is bound to the Hajj, and the Mu'tamir, when he finishes it, goes wherever he wants. Al-Husayn (peace be upon him) performed 'Umrah in Dhul-Hijjah, then he went to Iraq on the Day of Tarwiyah (8th of Dhul-Hijjah) while the people were going to Mina. So, there is no problem with performing 'Umrah in Dhul-Hijjah for one who does not intend to perform Hajj.
[1164] 6 - Muhammad ibn al-Hasan al-Saffar narrated from Muhammad ibn al-Husayn from Wuhaib ibn Hafs from Ali (peace be upon him), who said: Abu Basir asked him, and I was present, about someone who entered Ihram for ‘Umrah during the months of Hajj; is it permissible for him to return? He said: There is no ‘Umrah in the months of Hajj in which he returns to his family, but he is detained in Mecca until he performs his Hajj because he only entered Ihram for that.
Thus, he (peace be upon him) clarified in this narration that it is not permissible for him to do so because he entered Ihram for Hajj, and this only applies to one who intended to perform Tamattu‘ with ‘Umrah until Hajj, as we have explained.
226 - Chapter: Beginning with Medina is preferable for one who performs Hajj via the route of Iraq.
[1165] 1 - Musa ibn al-Qasim narrated from Safwan from 'Eis ibn al-Qasim, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about the pilgrim from Kufa, is it better to start with Medina or with Mecca? He said: With Medina.

[1176] 5 - From him, from Ṣafwān, from Mismaʿ, from Abū ʿAbd Allāh (peace be upon him), who said: He said to me, "If you enter Mecca, then perform the prayer in full (tamm) on the day you enter."
[1177] 6 - Muḥammad ibn ʿAlī ibn Maḥbūb, from Muḥammad ibn ʿAbd al-Jabbār, from Ṣafwān, from ʿAbd al-Raḥmān ibn al-Ḥajjāj, who said: I asked Abū ʿAbd Allāh (peace be upon him) about performing the prayer in full (itmām) in Mecca and Medina. He said: "Perform it in full (atimm), even if you only pray one prayer in them."
[1178] 7 - As for what Aḥmad ibn Muḥammad ibn ʿĪsā narrated, from Muḥammad ibn Ismāʿīl ibn Buzaygh, who said: I asked al-Riḍā (peace be upon him) about the prayer in Mecca and Medina, whether to shorten (taqṣīr) or perform in full (itmām)? He said: "Shorten (qaṣṣir) unless you resolve to stay for ten days."
[1179] 8 - From him, from ʿAlī ibn Ḥadīd, who said: I asked al-Riḍā (peace be upon him), and I said: "Our companions differ regarding the Two Sanctuaries (al-Ḥaramayn). Some of them shorten (yuqaṣṣir) and some perform in full (yutimm), and I am among those who perform in full (yutimm) based on a narration that our companions have narrated regarding the performance in full (itmām)." And I mentioned ʿAbd Allāh ibn Jundab, that he used to perform in full (yutimm). He said: "May God have mercy on Ibn Jundab." Then he said to me: "The performance in full (itmām) should only be if you resolve to stay for ten days, and pray the voluntary prayers (nawāfil) as you wish." Ibn Ḥadīd said: "And it was my desire that he order me to perform in full (itmām)."

There is no contradiction between these two reports and the preceding reports, because the order to shorten (taqṣīr) is only directed to the one who does not resolve to stay for ten days, if he believes in the obligation of performing in full (itmām) in them. And we did not say that the performance in full (itmām) in them is obligatory, but we only said it as a matter of virtue and recommendation. Do you not see the report of ʿAlī ibn Ḥadīd from al-Riḍā (peace be upon him), which included that when he mentioned ʿAbd Allāh ibn Jundab to him and that he used to perform in full (yutimm) in them, he asked for mercy upon him (taraḥḥama ʿalayhi). If his order to shorten (taqṣīr) was obligatory, he would not have asked for mercy upon him (lam yatarḥḥam ʿalayhi) because he was opposing him. Then ʿAlī ibn Ḥadīd also clarified that at the end of the report, because he said: "And it was my desire that he order me to perform in full (itmām)," so he clarified that he requested the obligation (al-wujūb), but he did not order him to do so, because their orders (awāmirihim) (peace be upon them)

text:
السلام تقتضي الوجوب ولم يقل ولم يندبني إليه، ويحتمل هذان الخبران وجها آخر وهو: أن من حصل بالحرمين ينبغي له أن يعزم على مقام عشرة أيام ويتم الصلاة فيهما وإن كان يعلم أنه لا يقيم إلا يوما أو يومين ويكون هذا مما يختص به هذان الموضعان ويتميزان به من سائر البلاد، لان سائر المواضع متى لم يعزم الانسان فيها على المقام عشرة أيام لم يجز له الاتمام، والذي يكشف عن هذا المعنى:
[1180] 9 - ما رواه محمد بن أحمد بن يحيى عن محمد بن عبد الجبار عن علي بن مهزيار عن محمد بن إبراهيم الحصيني قال: استأمرت أبا جعفر عليه السلام في الاتمام والتقصير قال: إذا دخلت الحرمين فانو عشرة أيام وأتم الصلاة فقلت: له إني أقدم مكة قبل التروية بيوم أو يومين أو ثلاثة قال: انو مقام عشرة وأتم الصلاة.
[1181] 10 - وأما ما رواه موسى بن القاسم عن عبد الرحمن عن معاوية بن وهب قال:
سألت أبا عبد الله عليه السلام عن التقصير في الحرمين والتمام؟ فقال: لا تتم حتى تجمع على مقام عشرة أيام فقلت: إن أصحابنا رووا عنك أنك أمرتهم بالتمام فقال:
إن أصحابك كانوا يدخلون المسجد فيصلون ويأخذون نعالهم ويخرجون والناس يستقبلونهم يدخلون المسجد للصلاة فأمرتهم بالتمام.
فالوجه في هذا الخبر انه لا يجب التمام إلا على من أجمع على مقام عشرة أيام ومتى لم يجمع على ذلك أن مخيرا بين الاتمام والتقصير وإن كان التمام أفضل، ويكون قوله عليه السلام لمن كان يخرج عند الصلاة من المسجد ولا يصلي مع الناس أمرا على الوجوب ولا يجوز تركه لمن هذا سبيله، لان فيه دفعا للتقية وإغراء بالنفس وتشنيعا على المذهب، والذي يكشف عما ذكرناه من أن هذا خرج مخرج التقية:
[1182] 12 - ما رواه محمد بن علي بن محبوب عن أحمد بن محمد عن الحسن بن الحسين

The salām (peace/greeting) necessitates obligation, yet He did not say, "nor did He recommend it to me." These two reports may also imply another interpretation: that whoever is present in the two Holy Sanctuaries (Mecca and Medina) should resolve to stay for ten days and perform the prayers in full, even if he knows he will only stay for a day or two. This would be a distinction specific to these two locations, setting them apart from all other lands. For in all other places, unless a person resolves to stay for ten days, it is not permissible for him to perform the prayers in full. What reveals this meaning is:
[1180] 9 - What Muhammad ibn Ahmad ibn Yahya narrated from Muhammad ibn 'Abd al-Jabbar from 'Ali ibn Mahziyar from Muhammad ibn Ibrahim al-Husayni, who said: I consulted Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) about performing prayers in full or shortening them. He said: "When you enter the two Holy Sanctuaries, intend to stay for ten days and perform the prayers in full." I said to him: "I arrive in Mecca one, two, or three days before the Day of Tarwiyah (8th of Dhu al-Hijjah)." He said: "Intend to stay for ten days and perform the prayers in full."
[1181] 10 - As for what Musa ibn al-Qasim narrated from 'Abd al-Rahman from Mu'awiyah ibn Wahb, who said:
I asked Abu 'Abd Allah (peace be upon him) about shortening or completing prayers in the two Holy Sanctuaries? He said: "Do not perform the prayers in full until you resolve to stay for ten days." I said: "Our companions have narrated from you that you ordered them to perform the prayers in full." He said: "Your companions used to enter the mosque, pray, take their sandals, and leave, while people were coming to the mosque to pray, so I ordered them to perform the prayers in full."
The interpretation of this report is that performing prayers in full is only obligatory upon one who resolves to stay for ten days. Whenever one does not resolve to do so, he is given a choice between performing the prayers in full or shortening them, although performing them in full is preferable. His (peace be upon him) statement to those who would leave the mosque at prayer time and not pray with the people is an order of obligation, and it is not permissible for one in that situation to abandon it, because it involves repelling taqiyya (dissimulation), endangering oneself, and bringing shame upon the madhhab (school of thought). What reveals that what we mentioned emerged as an instance of taqiyya (dissimulation) is:
[1182] 12 - What Muhammad ibn 'Ali ibn Mahbub narrated from Ahmad ibn Muhammad from al-Hasan ibn al-Husayn

اللؤلؤي عن صفوان عن عبد الرحمن بن الحجاج قال: قلت لأبي الحسن عليه السلام إن هشاما روى عنك أنك أمرته بالتمام في الحرمين وذلك من أجل الناس قال: لا كنت أنا ومن مضى من آبائي إذا وردنا مكة أتممنا الصلاة واستترنا من الناس.
والذي قدمناه من أنه ينبغي ان يجمع على المقام عشرة أيام أيضا محمول على الاستحباب، والذي يدل على ذلك:
[1183] 12 - ما رواه علي بن مهزيار قال: كتبت إلى أبي جعفر الثاني عليه السلام الرواية قد اختلفت عن آبائك عليه السلام في الاتمام والتقصير للصلاة في الحرمين، فمنها أن يأمر بتتميم الصلاة ولو صلاة واحدة، ومنها أن يأمر بقصر الصلاة ما لم ينو مقام عشرة أيام ولم أزل على الاتمام فيها إلى أن صدرنا من حجنا في عامنا هذا فإن فقهاء أصحابنا أشاروا علي بالتقصير إذا كنت لا أنوي مقام عشرة أيام وقد ضقت بذلك حتى أعرف رأيك؟ فكتب بخطه قد علمت يرحمك الله فضل الصلاة، في الحرمين على غيرهما فأنا أحب لك إذ دخلتهما ألا تقصر وتكثر فيهما من الصلاة فقلت: له بعد ذلك بسنتين مشافهة إني كتبت إليك بكذا وأجبت بكذا فقال: نعم فقلت: أي شئ تعني بالحرمين؟ فقال: مكة والمدينة ومتى إذا توجهت من منى فقصر الصلاة فإذا انصرفت من عرفات إلى منى وزرت البيت ورجعت إلى منى فأتم الصلاة تلك الثلاثة أيام وقال: بإصبعه ثلاثا.

الصلاة في أربعة مواطن في المسجد الحرام ومسجد الرسول صلى الله عليه وآله وفي مسجد الكوفة وحرم الحسين عليه السلام.
قال محمد بن الحسن: وليس لاحد أن يقول لأجل هذا الخبر والخبر الذي رواه حذيفة بن منصور أن الاتمام يختص بالمسجد الحرام ومسجد الكوفة فإذا خرج الانسان منهما فلا إتمام له، لأنه لا يمتنع أن يكون في هذين الخبرين قد خص الموضعان بالذكر تعظيما لهما، ثم ذكر في الاخبار الاخر ألفاظا يكون هذان المسجدان داخلين فيه وإن كان غيرهما داخلا فيه أيضا وهذا غير مستبعد ولا متناف، وقد قدمنا من الاخبار ما يتضمن عموم الأماكن التي من جملتها هذان المسجدان منها الخبر الأول عن حماد بن عيسى عن أبي عبد الله عليه السلام أنه قال: في حرم رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله وحرم أمير المؤمنين عليه السلام وبعده حديث زياد القندي أنه قال: أتم الصلاة في الحرمين وفي الكوفة ولم يقل في مسجد الكوفة، فأما ما قدمناه من الاخبار في تضمن ذكر الحرمين على الاطلاق فهي أكثر من أن تحصى، وإذا ثبت أن الاتمام في حرم الله وحرم رسوله صلى الله عليه وآله وهو المستحب دون المسجد على الاختصاص وإن كان قد خصا في هذين الخبرين فكذلك في مسجد الكوفة لان أحدا لا يفرق بين الموضعين.
تم الجزء الثاني من كتاب الاستبصار فيما اختلف من الاخبار ويتلوه انشاء الله تعالى الجزء الثالث وأوله كتاب الجهاد بحمد الله ومنه وحسن توفيقه

Prayer is [complete] in four locations: in the Sacred Mosque (al-Masjid al-Ḥarām), the Mosque of the Messenger (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family), the Mosque of Kufa, and the sanctuary of al-Husayn (peace be upon him).

Muhammad ibn al-Hasan said: No one can argue, based on this report and the report narrated by Hudhayfa ibn Mansur, that performing the complete prayer is exclusive to the Sacred Mosque and the Mosque of Kufa, such that if a person leaves these places, they cannot perform the complete prayer. This is because it is possible that these two locations were specifically mentioned in these two reports to emphasize their importance. Moreover, other reports contain general terms that include these two mosques, even if they include other places as well. This is not far-fetched or contradictory. We have already presented reports that include the general places, including these two mosques. Among these is the first report from Hammad ibn Isa, from Abi Abdillah (peace be upon him), who said: "In the sanctuary of the Messenger of God (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) and the sanctuary of Amir al-Mu'minin (peace be upon him)." Following that is the hadith of Ziyad al-Qindi, who said: "I performed the complete prayer in the two sanctuaries and in Kufa," and he did not say "in the Mosque of Kufa." As for what we presented of the reports that include mentioning the two sanctuaries in general terms, they are too many to count. If it is established that performing the complete prayer in the sanctuary of God and the sanctuary of His Messenger (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) is preferable, rather than being exclusive to the mosque in particular, even if they were specifically mentioned in these two reports, then the same applies to the Mosque of Kufa, because no one differentiates between the two locations.

End of Part Two of the book *Al-Istibsar fima ukhtalif min al-akhbar* (Insight into the Differences in Narrations). Part Three follows, God willing, beginning with the Book of Jihad, with the praise, help, and gracious guidance of God.
